justification: “When rewards were offered immediately a single value-related signal was identified at two locations: the ventral striatum (VS) and the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC).” This identifies VS activity as the instrument used to index the construct of subjective value.
The same sentence notes that the value-related signal was also found in the vmPFC, indicating that BOLD activation in this region served to measure subjective value.

“It was definitively shown that firing rates could be observed in the parietal cortex that tightly correlated with the economic notion of expected utility.” Thus neuronal firing in PPC was used to quantify the utility representation construct.

measured_by: hyperbolic decline of vmPFC & VS activity across delays
justification: “A detailed characterization of the vmPFC and VS activity revealed that the signal precisely captured… the hyperbolic later decline in value with time. The data revealed that this single brain activation was just as intransitive as the individual.” The delay-related change in these signals operationalises temporal discounting.

measured_by: asymmetric BOLD responses in valuation-related brain areas
justification: Regarding Tom et al. (2007): “Brain activity was examined as decision-makers evaluated financial lotteries… the study revealed that a number of brain areas irrationally encoded losses and gains asymmetrically,” showing those BOLD asymmetries were the measure of loss-aversion.

measured_by: shifts in willingness-to-pay bids in the snack auction task
justification: Describing Khaw, Louie & Glimcher (2017): “Hungry subjects were asked to indicate the maximum amount they would pay for each of 30 different snacks… After the change, subjects transiently shifted their bids downwards… exactly the effect that would be expected if an efficient coding system… was re-centering.” The bid shifts serve as the behavioral measure of reference-point adaptation.
